entry.title: Make Time
entry.content:
I have caught myself a few times lately, staring at my daughters, mouth agape, in wonder an awe about how quickly they are growing up.  Time marches past us all with no regard to how much fun we are currently having - and like Ferris said life moves pretty fast.  You really need to stop and look around from time to time.

And it does move fast.  A month ago marked the 1st anniversarry of my cousin Pete’s passing.  Peter taught me many things about life, but the biggest of which is truly like that quote from the 80’s hit movie… life goes fast.

In the past year I have tried to make it a point, made it a goal in my life to stop and look around more often.  Watch my girls grow in front of my eyes.  Spend more time with those I love.  And spend more time doing the things I love.  It has been amazingly rewarding.

So with the summer break quickly running out of time, I decided to make some time, and “look around a little”.

Fishmaster in Redding

 The first trip I took was down to Redding, CA to help my cousin pack up for a big move back to Spokane.  Amanda is an amazing person who has been through so much in the past year, it was the very least I could do… and I was also really looking forward to hanging with her awesome kiddos too.

Time was made and spent doing fun things.  Watching Diary of A Wimpy Kid, hanging with neighbors at a pool party, garage saleing, reminicing about Pete, and of course fishing with Ethan.  Nothing is more magical than hanging out with a kid that is doing what they love.  Nothing.  Stop reading this blog post, and go out and do it, and be inspired. 

Backpacking Bear

I have been wanting to take Kaydee on her first “real” camping trip for quite sometime.  No trailer, no car camping, the real kind.  Hiking in, and enjoying nature.  So a few weekends ago we did just so.  Left home Friday afternoon, and went up to Little Three Creeks Lake.  The hike wasn’t long - under 2 miles in fact, but it didn’t matter.  We were camping.

My pack outweighed hers by 40lbs easily… but I would have been willing to carry 40 more for the experience.  Setting up the tent, mac n cheese in a bag, climbing rocks in an alpine meadow, and skpping stones next to a bubbling spring - all of these moments and many more are priceless.

As I write this though, some of those magical spots are now being burned in the Pole Creek fire - I guess it was good we made time to get out there when we did - a whole one day before the fire broke out.

 

So to the loyal blog readers, who actually read this far… Get out, make time, and do the things you love with the ones you love.  And be sure to write about it, and spread the smiles around to a world that can use more things to smile about.

entry.title: A River Full of Awesomeness
entry.content:
Simply put: Today is Awesome.  First thing this morning I got to go out to breakfast with all my girls, and then I loaded up beatrice and headed East to the Crooked River Gorge.

The place is so beautiful, and the temperatures were super pleasant today.  The fish even cooperated by jumping onto my flies at least a dozen or so times throughout the day.  Living the dream LOVING the dream!

entry.title: Riviere aux Chutes
entry.content:
Amazingly awesome weekend playing, in and around the Deschutes River.  Sometimes I can’t believe how lucky I am to walk out my front door, walk 5 minutes, and be fishing in such a stunning place.

My stoke only got higher when I landed my first fish (minnow?  it was like 5” long), and was equally as stoked when the second one (8 inches of pure furry) gulped up my parachute adams.  So fantastic to be waded out in the river, casting away.

Finished up Saturday with a family bike ride to the park, a mere stroll from my little fishing hole.

Today I started off the day running down the river trail and then I got to fish the deschutes near FS road 40.  The skeeters were fierce, and even without deet I managed to land a 9” brown.

So.

Much.

Fun.

entry.title: Whole Wheat Banana Bread
entry.content:
I have been trying some variations on a “Mom Classic” the past few weeks, and have finally refined the recipe down to something that is just waaaaay yummy. Teagan, in fact, just ate 3 pieces of this (thats a lot of fiber for a little one, bombs coming soon).

So here is the recipe as it currently stands:

* 1/2 Cup Organic Evaporated Cane Juice * 3 TSP Agave Nectar


* 2 cups (sifted first) Bob’s Red Mill Whole Wheat Flour
* 2 TSP Baking Soda
* 1/2 TSP Salt
* 2 Large Eggs
* 4 oz Organic Applesauce (no sugar added)
* 3 TSP Coconut Oil (melted)
* 4 Very Ripe Bananas (as my mom said this weekend, ripe ones are better than ones that have been in the freezer)
* 1 cup of Raisins

Preheat oven to 350, and grease/flour a bread pan.

1) In a large mixing bowl, cream together sugar, agave, applesauce, coconut oil, and eggs.

2) Sift together flour, salt, and baking soda.

3) And in another bowl, mash bananas.

4) Mix 1 cup sifted dry ingredients into the creamed sugar / oil mixture

5) Add 1/2 the mashed bananas, mix

6) Repeat steps 4 & 5 with remaining ingredients, and toss in Raisins and mix. Pour into greased/floured bread pan.

I bake the bread for 30 minutes at 350, then cover loosely with foil and bake for around another 20 minutes. Check with a toothpick and when it comes clean it is ready.

entry.title: Memories and Dreams
entry.content:
Memorial weekend most definitely conjured up memories for me.

Even though the weekend started out with an unexpected twist - Becky staying home due to a stomach bug - and was a quite busy one overall - there were a few moments where memories from the past came rushing back to me like a dream sequence.

When I first walked into my parents house, my eyes kept darting to the back door, looking for the pups there waiting to come in - or eagerly waiting for a handout from Grandma :).  This dream of a memory happened numerous times during my visit.

Sorrow of missing friends no longer around was quickly hidden away by the creation of wonderful new memories - ones that I’m sure someday will come back to me and spark similar nostalgia when I walk through those doors.

Memories of the smiles shared with grandparents, playing with cousins, and laughter and happiness.

Before I set out for the long drive home (360 miles with two kids is daunting), I walked back to a dreamscape.  I visited the meadow we often went to with our friends… though the grass was green and lush from the spring rains, my mind quickly turned it dry, and a breeze whisked through the tall grass.

I walked through the tall dry grass just like Chinook loved to do - felt it touch my skin and lived the memory as a dream all over again.  Big doggie smiles, loving the moment.  I missed them all: Becky, Sophie, and Chinook, but they were with me there in that moment.  In that dream.

entry.title: Campin
entry.content:
This weekend we got to take the new Trailer for its maiden voyage.  Due to a recent issue with the truck - we decided to stay kinda close to home and drove up to Bachelor.

2 beauty evenings and days.  Warm temps, soft snow.  A good time was had by all.

entry.title: Lessons From a Dog
entry.content:
I find that writing helps me cope with sorrow.  And since my life has served me up a massive dump truck of sorrow in the past day, here is a blog post about the source of the sorrow: the departure of one of my best friends: Chinook.

Backstory

I have blogged about Chinook before but for those just joining into my story, or to be hip, the tl;dr; (meaning of tl;dr; for my mom: too long, didn’t read) version will be dropped right here.  Chinook was “the best birthday present ever” that I gave to my then girlfriend, now wife, Becky, about 11 and a half years ago.

As Becky put it, our lives as “grown ups” (I chuckle at that term, though I guess I am grown up) have always had Chinook in it.  Any dog owner/lover knows, our pets are such a huge part of our lives.. and at many darker points in our journeys, dogs can often be our only source of hope.

Anyhow, that old post sums up a good part of the history of Chinook.  But in death, saddly enough, we often discover just how important someone, or in this case, a dog is to our lives.

Last night I held Chinook’s big head while he went to sleep, and took his last breath, and through the tears ( I have sobbed so freaking much, and will obviously continue to do so ), and *so many* happy memories I kept realizing I have learned so much from my best buddy Chinook.

So, as an ode to the life of my buddy, my amazingly awesome big ass dog, I want to jot down some of the things he taught me.  Because these lessons are gold, and if followed, hopefully I too can live a long life full of hapiness like he did.

Size Matters

Chinook was a big boy.  He tipped the scales, that is when he would even lay paw in the dr’s office, at over 145lbs.  But the beauty of him was he was so gentle and loving for his size.  And the only thing that was bigger than his physial size (and massive head) was the love he would pour out on anyone around him.

Love big, love often.  Size does matter when it comes to the love you give others.

Be a Leaner

Another awesome thing Chinook would do was to come up to nearly anyone sitting on a chair or a couch, and sit directly on their feet.  This many times resulted in “brown ones” on a pair of socks, but more importnatly, Chinook would then lean into you, and beg for love.

To borrow from the lyrics of an epic 80’s song, we all need someone to lean on from time to time.  Looking back over my various jobs, and other aspects of my life, I can distinctly point out times where if I simply would have been a ‘leaner’ like Chinook, the rough road I was traveling on would have been so much smoother.

Surround yourself with people you can saunter up to and lean on… make yourself available for them to lean back on you as well.  Just don’t leave brown ones.

Okay to be Scared

Even if you are a big dog, life can be freaking scary at times.  Chinook was quite possibly the biggest wimp dog ever.  Thunder, fireworks, doorways, wind, you name it, Chinook was spooked easily.

Simply put though, life throws some scary stuff at us.  Getting married, starting a new job, having kids, and making hard decisions like putting a dog down suck, and are scary.  Its okay to be scared, and when scared, find the nearest foot to sit on.

(side note: tonight I was out front of our house, and there were three loud claps of thunder over a five minute span.  I was elated.  I ran inside and told Becky.  I was so happy Chinook didn’t hear the thunder and also I thought it was a sign.  Call me crazy. I don’t care )

Most Importantly: Live In The Now

Hands down the biggest thing I learned from Chinook, and am still trying to perfect, is living in the now.  Chinook was stoked in the moment.  He was present whether lounging on the carpet, or chilling in the shade during a hot summer hike.

In the era of pads, smart phones, and the interwebs, we are bombarded with distractions that prevent us from fully living in the moment.  I know the times I am happiest are when all that noise is off, and I’m out in nature, living in the present.

He helped me live in the now on a daily basis.  Sometimes we would wrestle on the ground, other times we would spoon, whatever it was, we just enjoyed eachother.  Living in the moment with those around you, those you love, is such a beautiful thing that we should all practice more often.

But even bigger here is you never know how many moments you will be blessed with from a particular person, or pet.  Life is fragile and precious, soak up each opportunity you have with those you love, and savor it.

Lessons From My Friend

Chinook was so much more than a dog.  And the lessons he taught me and others are much greater than this quick list.  The love he gave me was so wonderful, and I miss him very much.  So grab someone (human/canine) and hold them tight, and tell them you love them, and remind them of how much they mean to you.

entry.title: Bacon, Chicken, Pabst
Birthday Month
entry.content:
My lovely wife has introduced me to many things over the past 10 years - but after this week, I think the greatest of these is the concept of “Birthday Month”.

Everyone loves birthdays, but Becky is especially keen on them.  So much so that she likes to spread the celebration much longer than just a day, in fact she likes to observe the date for the entire month.

So here I am, winding down my 35th birthday month, and the past week(ish) has simply been awesome.

A week ago I was shredding pow in B.C. with my good friend Jon, and today, I skiined up my favorite little butte in a blizzard.

Between here and ther my girls threw me a pimpin birthday party (complete with a 35 candle cake), I spoke at Ignite Bend, and got to spend a lovely daddy Friday with my two littlest girls.

So the stoke carried on today over miles of sledneck fash shots, a great little lap down botomless pow, and the first descent of the Sheridan Shelter.

Birthday Month, FTW.

5/22

entry.title: stawamus chief
entry.content:
When you don’t want to spend $96 CAD on a lift ticket, you can go do other super cool stuff in Squamish.  A good time was had by all, though Jon gets kinda spooked on top of exposed ridges… teee heee.

Quite an amazing trail up the side of the chief.  Intricate granite steps, stairs, all alongside a waterfall.  Its like a little slice of the valley… I can see whey people love to live here.
